wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the system overview focused on the MineContext application. Explain its purpose as a context-aware productivity tool that captures digital activities and transforms them into AI-powered insights. Describe the high-level architecture including the Electron frontend, Python backend, and their integration. Document the core components: context capture, data processing, AI integration, and user interface. Include conceptual diagrams showing the overall system flow from capture to insight presentation. Provide use cases for developers and end-users. Explain the relationship between major components and how they interact through IPC and HTTP APIs. Include practical examples of common workflows like application startup and manual capture. Address architectural decisions and trade-offs made in the hybrid desktop application design.

wiki_catalogs.name: Electron Process Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Electron process architecture in MineContext. Describe the three-process model: main process for system-level operations and window management, renderer process for React UI rendering, and preload scripts for secure context bridging. Explain the responsibilities of each process: main process handles system integration, IPC communication, and Python backend management; renderer process manages UI components and user interactions; preload scripts securely expose limited Node.js APIs to the renderer. Document the security considerations in the context isolation implementation and how sensitive operations are restricted to the main process. Detail the lifecycle management of the Electron application from startup in index.ts to window creation and event handling. Include examples of how the backend.ts file manages the Python subprocess lifecycle and communicates with the backend service.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the frontend structure focused on the MineContext Electron application. Explain the separation between main, preload, and renderer processes in Electron architecture. Detail the role of the main process in window management, lifecycle handling, and IPC communication. Describe the preload script's function in securely exposing Node.js APIs to the renderer. Explain the React-based renderer process with its component hierarchy, state management using Jotai/Redux, and styling with Tailwind CSS. Include information about the build configuration via electron-builder and Vite, and how the frontend communicates with the Python backend through HTTP and IPC. Provide practical examples from the codebase such as window creation in index.ts and IPC channel setup in IpcChannel.ts. Address security considerations in context isolation and nodeIntegration settings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the backend service components of MineContext. Describe the three core managers: ContextCaptureManager, ContextProcessorManager, and ConsumptionManager. Explain how the ContextCaptureManager registers, initializes, and controls lifecycle of capture components like screenshot and web link capture. Detail how the ContextProcessorManager routes raw context data through appropriate processors based on source type using its routing table, and manages periodic memory compression via the merger component. Document the ConsumptionManager's role in generating AI-powered insights through scheduled tasks for activity reports, smart tips, and todo generation. Explain how these managers are initialized and wired together in component_initializer.py, including the callback chain from capture to processing to consumption. Include thread safety considerations, statistics tracking, and shutdown procedures for each manager.

wiki_catalogs.name: Content Chunking Strategies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the content chunking strategies used in MineContext's data processing pipeline. Explain the purpose of chunking in breaking down large captured content (documents, screenshots, web pages) into semantically meaningful units for downstream AI processing. Detail the implementation in chunkers.py, including the Chunker class hierarchy and routing logic based on context type. Describe the document_text_chunker.py implementation for text-based documents, including text splitting algorithms, overlap strategies, and metadata preservation. Document the configuration options for chunk size, overlap, and language-specific processing. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how raw text is transformed into ProcessedContext chunks. Explain integration points with the processor pipeline and how chunking affects retrieval accuracy and LLM performance. Address common issues such as over-chunking, under-chunking, and handling of special content types.

wiki_catalogs.name: Screenshot Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the screenshot monitoring feature focused on MineContext's screen capture capabilities. Explain how the ScreenshotCapture class implements the ICaptureComponent interface and integrates with the CaptureManager. Detail the implementation of the capture() method that uses system-level window capture utilities to take screenshots at configured intervals. Describe the configuration options in config.yaml including capture_interval, image_quality, and excluded_applications. Document how the system handles different display configurations and monitors. Include examples from screenshot.py showing how raw image data is packaged into RawContextProperties with metadata like window title, application name, and timestamp. Address performance considerations such as memory usage during continuous capture and strategies for minimizing system impact. Explain error handling for scenarios like permission denial or display access failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Files
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the configuration files used in MineContext, focusing on config.yaml, prompts_en.yaml, and prompts_zh.yaml. Explain the structure and purpose of config.yaml as the central configuration file that controls capture settings, processing behavior, AI integration parameters, and system-wide options. Document each major section including capture, processing, llm, storage, and monitoring with examples from the actual file. Describe how prompts_en.yaml and prompts_zh.yaml store AI prompt templates for multilingual support and how they are utilized by the PromptManager to generate context-aware responses. Provide concrete examples showing how changes in these YAML files affect application behavior. Explain validation rules, default values, and schema structure. Include guidance on best practices for modifying configurations and avoiding common syntax errors.

Explain the LLMClient class that serves as the primary interface for all LLM interactions, including chat completions, streaming responses, and embedding generation. Describe the embedding generation functionality with vectorize and vectorize_async methods that convert text to vector representations. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how the client handles different LLM types (CHAT and EMBEDDING) and providers (including OpenAI and Volcengine/Doubao). Address error handling strategies, token usage monitoring, and performance measurement through request timing.

Document the event propagation mechanism that sends power state changes to the renderer process via IPC. Include examples from the codebase showing how the application pauses context capture during system sleep and resumes when the system wakes up. Explain the logging strategy and error handling for power-related operations. Address platform-specific behaviors and considerations for different operating systems.

Document the environment setup, dependency installation, and execution for both frontend and backend components. wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# MineContext Project Overview

## 1. Project Introduction

MineContext is a sophisticated Electron-based desktop application that combines frontend and backend components to create a context-aware productivity tool. The application captures user activities, processes contextual information, and provides AI-powered insights through a React-based interface.

**Purpose Statement**: MineContext aims to enhance user productivity by automatically capturing digital activities (screenshots, documents, web links) and transforming them into actionable insights using AI and machine learning.

**Core Goals and Objectives**:
- Capture and organize user digital context across applications
- Process captured data using AI models for intelligent insights
- Provide a seamless desktop experience with background monitoring
- Enable users to retrieve and analyze their digital activities

**Target Audience**: Knowledge workers, researchers, and professionals who need to track and analyze their digital activities for productivity enhancement and knowledge management.

Sources:
- [README.md](/Users/shenli/Projects/holly/MineContext-main/README.md)

## 2. Technical Architecture

The MineContext application follows a hybrid architecture with a frontend Electron application and a Python-based backend service. The system is designed with clear separation between the UI layer, business logic, and data processing components.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Electron Frontend] --> B[Main Process]
    A --> C[Renderer Process]
    B --> D[Backend Service]
    D --> E[(SQLite Database)]
    D --> F[(File Storage)]
    D --> G[LLM Services]
    B --> H[IPC Communication]
    C --> H
    H --> D
    D --> I[External APIs]
```

The architecture consists of several key components:

1. **Frontend Layer**: Built with Electron, React, and TypeScript, providing a desktop application interface
2. **Main Process**: Handles system-level operations, IPC communication, and backend service management
3. **Backend Service**: Python-based service for context processing, AI operations, and API endpoints
4. **Data Storage**: SQLite for structured data and file system for unstructured data like screenshots
5. **AI Integration**: LLM clients for generating insights from captured context

The application uses a microservices-like approach within a single desktop application, with the frontend and backend communicating through HTTP APIs and Electron's IPC mechanism.

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points

The application's entry point is the Electron main process, which initializes the application and manages the lifecycle of both the frontend and backend components.

- **Frontend Entry**: `frontend/src/main/index.ts`
- **Backend Management**: `frontend/src/main/backend.ts`
- **Electron Configuration**: `frontend/package.json`

### Core Modules

**Frontend Components**:
- `frontend/src/main/services/DatabaseService.ts`: Manages SQLite database operations
- `frontend/src/main/services/ScreenshotService.ts`: Handles screenshot capture and management
- `frontend/src/main/background/task/screen-monitor-task.ts`: Implements the screen monitoring functionality

**Backend Components**:
- `opencontext/server/api.py`: Backend API endpoints
- `opencontext/context_processing/processor/`: Data processing pipelines
- `opencontext/llm/llm_client.py`: LLM integration

### Configuration Approach

The application uses a hierarchical configuration system with YAML files for settings and environment variables for runtime configuration.

- `config/config.yaml`: Primary configuration file
- `config/prompts_en.yaml`: AI prompt templates
- `frontend/.env.example`: Environment variables template

### External Dependencies

The project relies on several key external dependencies:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[MineContext] --> B[Electron]
    A --> C[React]
    A --> D[TypeScript]
    A --> E[Python]
    A --> F[SQLite]
    A --> G[LLM APIs]
    B --> H[Chromium]
    B --> I[Node.js]
    G --> J[OpenAI Compatible]
```

Key dependencies include:
- Electron for desktop application framework
- React for UI components
- TypeScript for frontend type safety
- Python for backend processing
- SQLite for local data storage
- AI/ML libraries for context analysis

### Integration Points

The application integrates various system and external services:

- **System Integration**: Desktop capturing, file system access, system tray
- **API Integration**: LLM services, web APIs
- **Data Integration**: Document processing, web link capture

## 4. Key Features

### Context Capture and Monitoring

The application provides comprehensive context capture capabilities, including screenshot monitoring and activity tracking.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Monitoring: Start Recording
    Monitoring --> Capturing: Timer Trigger
    Capturing --> Processing: Image Captured
    Processing --> Storing: Save to Disk
    Storing --> Monitoring: Ready for Next
    Monitoring --> Idle: Stop Recording
```

The screen monitoring feature captures screenshots at regular intervals and processes them through the backend service for analysis.

### Data Processing Pipeline

The application implements a sophisticated data processing pipeline that transforms raw captured data into meaningful insights.

```mermaid
flowchart LR
    A[Screenshots] --> B[Processor]
    C[Documents] --> B
    D[Web Links] --> B
    B --> E[Chunker]
    E --> F[Merger]
    F --> G[Storage]
    G --> H[LLM]
    H --> I[Insights]
```

The processing pipeline includes:
- Data ingestion from multiple sources
- Content chunking for efficient processing
- Context merging to create comprehensive views
- Storage in both database and vector formats
- AI analysis to generate insights

### User Interface and Experience

The React-based frontend provides a modern user interface with several key components:

- **Home Page**: Overview of recent activities and insights
- **Screen Monitor**: Real-time monitoring controls and visualization
- **Settings**: Configuration of capture parameters and AI models
- **Vault**: Document and context management

The UI is built with React components and uses state management patterns to maintain application state across different views.

### AI-Powered Insights

The application leverages AI models to generate intelligent insights from captured context:

- **Smart Tips**: Context-aware suggestions based on user activities
- **Task Management**: AI-assisted to-do list generation and prioritization
- **Content Generation**: Automated content creation from captured context

The AI integration is implemented through the LLM client modules, which connect to external AI services to process data and generate responses.

Sources:
- [index.ts](/Users/shenli/Projects/holly/MineContext-main/frontend/src/main/index.ts)
- [backend.ts](/Users/shenli/Projects/holly/MineContext-main/frontend/src/main/backend.ts)
- [DatabaseService.ts](/Users/shenli/Projects/holly/MineContext-main/frontend/src/main/services/DatabaseService.ts)
- [ScreenshotService.ts](/Users/shenli/Projects/holly/MineContext-main/frontend/src/main/services/ScreenshotService.ts)
- [screen-monitor-task.ts](/Users/shenli/Projects/holly/MineContext-main/frontend/src/main/background/task/screen-monitor-task.ts)
</blog>
